column1: A renal venogram is a test to look at the veins in the kidney.
X-rays are a form of electromagnetic radiation like light, but of higher energy, so they can move through the body to form an image.
This test is done in a hospital.
The health care provider places a needle into a vein, most often in the groin.
Next, a flexible tube called a catheter (which is the width of the tip of a pen) is inserted into the groin and moved through the vein until it reaches the vein in the kidney.
Your doctor may tell you to stop taking aspirin or other blood thinners before the test.
It's most common use today is as part of an exam to treat varicose veins of the testicles or ovaries.
There should not be any clots or tumors in the kidney vein.
